subject: Re: [junit] Initailizing Objects in Test Cases from a TestSuite
msgSnippet: ... Google Abstract Test Cases . You can run one set of common tests for all three implementations where the only difference is how to create the object under
messageBody:
Nathaniel Troutman wrote:
> Hello all,
>
> I'm a Sophmore in College and have been programming for several years
> in various languages. This semester I'm in Data Structures and our
> first project is to write implementations of a List. Our classes
> implement a ListADT interface, but we have to write three different
> implementations, one using Fixed Arrays, on that can "Dynamically"
> resize arrays, and a Link List. We also have to write a tests to
> ensure our list implementations are good. Having heard of JUnit I
> thought this would be a good time to learn it. So far it has worked
> fine for testing a single implementation. I have several TestCase
> classes testing different aspects of the list, and have added them to
> a sutie so that they can be all be run at once. However, I want to be
> able to test all three implementations at once in on fell swoop, with
> out having to write three sets of test cases and three test suites.

Google "Abstract Test Cases". You can run one set of common tests for
all three implementations where the only difference is how to create the
object under test.

Alternatively, if your bookstore carries _JUnit Recipes_, check out
chapter 2. (If it doesn't, complain.)
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
2005 Gordon Pask Award Winner for contribution to Agile practice
Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
